1.content:
“Do you really think so?”

Teddy nodded fervently. Well, if he was this dedicated to it, you guessed you were too.

“Alright, on three. One, two, three!”

The two of you sprung out from behind the stack of boxes you had been hiding behind and began lobbing tomatoes at the blonde heads of the school cheerleaders. One of the tomatoes hit the lead cheerleader right in the forehead. She squealed and ran off, hands in the air. The other cheerleaders followed soon after.

You grinned. Those girls deserved that, after all they’d done to you and Teddy’s mutual friend, Brenda. Mocking her, stealing her gym clothes while she wasn’t looking, writing fake love letters to the most popular guy in school. Man, teenagers really were animals.

You were brought down from your high when you saw that one of the cheerleaders had stayed behind to confront the two of you.

“Oh, shit.”

It was Missy, the most popular girl in the school and the one who had initiated Brenda’s bullying. She had her hands on her hips and a scowl on her face. “You two assholes better stop this shit or I’m telling my daddy. He can snap his fingers and have your parents fired from their shitty little jobs at the factory.” Ah, life in small town America. The only place where you could have a single person rule over more than half the town and have the threat of unemployment from a spoiled, bratty little girl have actual weight.

Teddy spluttered. “Hey, you don’t have to do that! We’re actually really sorry! We’ll even clean your clothes for you-- wait, I mean--” He realized his mistake too late. Missy’s face turned red and she slapped Teddy in the face. Teddy yelped and clutched the throbbing red mark where she’d hit him. “Owww…”

Missy stormed out of the room, arms at her sides and blonde ponytail bobbing. You’d be lying if you said you didn’t think she was hot. But enough of that! You had a wounded friend to tend to!

“You alright, dude?”

He nodded and hid his face, his other cheek turning a vivid shade of red from sheer embarrassment. You patted him on the back and the two of you left the gymnasium to finally head home after another day of the hell that was highschool.

Brenda was waiting for the two of you outside, backpack slung over her shoulder. She waved at the two of you. You waved back with a smile on your face. Brenda wasn’t exactly a model, but she was cute in her own nerdy way. You’d thought about dating her a couple of times, but every time you came to the conclusion that it would just be too awkward. She adjusted her coke bottle glasses and gave you a high-five. Hell yeah!

“How did it go?”

You smiled. “We made them pay. They’ll think twice before pushing you down the stairs again.” Really, you should have done a lot worse than embarrassing them at the end of the day, but you didn’t want to get in trouble again. You were already on the verge of being kicked out. Your dad was angry enough as it was.

Brenda gave you a crooked smile. You patted her on the back and made your way down the sidewalk to the front of the school, where your bikes were chained up. A quick turn of the combination lock later and you and Teddy were on your way home. The two of you lived in separate neighborhoods, but they were both the same direction away from school.

“So, Derek, what are you up to tonight? Got any plans?” Teddy looked genuinely curious for once. He probably wanted to hang out. It was too bad you couldn’t make it tonight.

“Oh, just the regular. I’m going to hop on the computer and get some research done!” That was true enough. You had been hard at work on a story that would hopefully become your first book. Teddy thought it was a little weird that you were obsessing so much over a piece of writing, but he didn’t know how it felt to create with just your mind and your raw imagination. It was indescribable to someone who had never experienced it.

Teddy’s face fell. You guessed he could tell you weren’t up for the hang out tonight. You smiled wanly at him. “Hey, next time, we’ll definitely hang out. For now...I’ve got to be heading home. See ya, man! Have a good evening!” You waved Teddy goodbye and split down the intersection towards your house.

Man, you hated doing Teddy like that. He was a good friend. But you had to get your research done...ah, who were you kidding. Most of your research devolved into random music video sessions. That turned into a whole lot of behind the scenes videos, too. Very little research was actually done. Your book had stalled at chapter four. Maybe it would stay there forever.

These were the thoughts running through your head as it happened. As you crossed in front of a local playground, you saw a blue streak of light shooting through the sky, straight at...you! You hopped off of your bike just in time to see the blue streak crash into the swingset, utterly destroying it in the process. A massive cloud of dirt shot up from the impact point.

“Woah.” You looked around, to see if anyone had seen or heard what just happened, Nobody was standing outside with their phones up, so you guessed that was a big no. You stopped your bike at the curb and hopped off, eager to investigate this seemingly random cosmic occurrence.
At the center of a surprisingly large crater, there was a single blue rock. It was smooth and somewhat oblong. It gave you the impression of an overly large egg. Hadn’t you read that somewhere before? You crouched down at the edge of the crater and poked the rock with a curious finger. The stone was surprisingly cool to the touch, for something that was smoking just a few seconds ago. When nothing happened, you picked up the rock with both hands and dumped it into the outermost pocket of your backpack.

You’d have to take a closer look at it later, in the safety of your own home. Out here, anyone could come looking for it. And that was the last thing you wanted. No, this precious gem was yours.

You continued on your way home, bicycling past the police cars that were zooming past you towards the impact site. Soon, they were joined by big black vans. Well, one thing was for sure-- whatever that rock was, somebody was looking for it.

Too bad for them.
1.title: Out of the Blue

choices: “I don’t even know if you’re telling the truth. Prove you can change reality.”
“I’ve got a couple of ideas for things you could do with my family.”
“Let me call my friends over! They have to see this!"
“I think our fun can wait until school.”
“I’m obviously very high or very drunk. I think I’m gonna go to sleep.”
11.content:
You pulled up onto your front lawn and hopped off your bike. After walking your bike into your garage (your dad’s garage, as he always insisted on correcting you), you made your way into the house proper. You crossed your fingers, hoping and praying that she wouldn’t be in the living room.

“Hey bro! Why are you in such a hurry?”

No such luck.

Your little sister waved to you from the couch. Angela was such an annoyance, you swore to god. She just loved getting under your skin. She was only eleven, but that didn’t stop her from being a total demon.

“I was just heading upstairs. Nothing else is happening here. Nope, nothing at all.”

Angela raised an eyebrow. “Yeah, sure. I really believe that. You’re hiding something, bro. More than usual, I mean.”

You shrugged. “I don’t know what you mean.”

“Hey, is that Derek?” Your mom’s voice. She was probably taking care of something in her downstairs office. It seemed she spent almost all of her time in there nowadays.

“Yeah, it’s me! I was just heading up to my room when Angela decided to stop me.”

“Hey, be nice to your sister, okay? She’s going through a rough time.”

You didn’t know and you didn’t want to know. Instead you just held your hands up and surrendered. “Okay, mom. I’ll be nice to Angela.”

Angela stomped her foot. “I’m right here, you know!”

You tilted your head and forced a smile onto your face. “I know. Sorry Angela. I’ll be nicer to you from now on.”

She smirked and hopped her way back to the couch. “Oh, I’m sure of it!”

You could hear the smile in your mother’s voice as she lauded you. “Thank you, Derek! Have a good time upstairs.”

A good time? You raised an eyebrow and clomped your way upstairs. You were glad your dad wasn’t home yet. You weren’t sure you could deal with that level of bullshit this early in the day.

With that thought, you opened the door into your humble little bedroom. It wasn’t much to look at. You had a twin bed with a hilariously outdated Scooby-Doo bedcover, a small desk where your laptop was charging, and a tiny table with a suitably small lamp. The walls were plastered with posters of your favorite celebrities (read: K-pop girls). You had Momoland, Twice, and Oh My Girl in positions of honor right above your bed. They were usually the last things you saw before you fell asleep.

But enough of your lameness, you had a strange space rock to look at. Without wasting any more time, you tore the rock out of your backpack and placed it carefully on your desk, next to your laptop. You sat down and began to pick away at the rock with a screwdriver you’d stolen from your dad’s toolbox in the garage. Nothing seemed to happen. You weren’t even sure what you were expecting. Some kind of blue light? A genie in the bottle? Neither came to be.

You began to get a little frustrated. Surely something as incredible as this rock held secrets beyond the surface. You picked the thing up with both hands and held it up to your face. “Come on! Show me something cool!”

The rock lit up with a vibrant blue light. It suddenly become very hot to the touch. With a gasp, you dropped it back onto your desk. It didn’t stop glowing. If anything, the light got brighter. The rock began to shake from side to side, as if possessed. You shielded your eyes with the back of your hand.

When the light finally stopped, you lowered your hand, only to come face to face with a cloud of blue dust in the shape of a woman. That was the best way you could describe it. It was kind of amorphous, but it was unmistakably alive.

Yeah, the rock had done something cool, alright.

The cloud began to speak. “Hello, hello, testing one two three! Wow, this is so interesting! It’s been a while since I’ve been to three-dee land. I’ve forgotten how simple you all are. And Earth...ooh, intelligent life is so much fun to play with!”

You took a couple of steps back, jaw thoroughly dropped. “Are you-- are you an alien?”

“Hmmm...what an interesting question! Well, the answer is...sorta yes, sorta no? I originate not too far from here from a four-dimensional perspective...but from a three-dimensional one it’s...difficult to explain.”

“Fourth dimension? So you’re like that one Superman villain?”

The cloud seemed to shrug. “In terms of powers, sure. But he and I couldn’t be any more different in terms of mentality. Or maybe not. It’s all a little orange and blue to you three-dee-landers.”

She floated past you, over to your bed. She took a close look at the covers. “Hmm. Scooby-Doo. You like this show even though you shouldn’t. It’s way below your age group. At least that’s what you think. And your favorite character is...her.”

She snapped her fingers, and in an instant she had reshaped into the form of Velma Dinkley, orange turtleneck sweater and all. You blinked. “How did you do that? That’s just...impossible!”

She adjusted her glasses and winked at you. “I specialize in the impossible. As to how...I’m a reality shifter. I manipulate the third dimension like you breathe air.”

You took a step back. “But why?”

She shrugged. “This one’s your favorite, right? Velma Dinkley. She has a catchphrase too, doesn’t she? What is it, Jinkies?” She hummed softly to herself. “I think that’s what I’ll call myself for right now. It works as well as anything.”

“How did you get here? What do you want with me?”

She rolled her eyes. “So many questions! I got here as part of a, hmm, a prison break, I guess you could say.” You raised your eyebrows. “It wasn’t a violent crime, don’t worry. As for what I want with you? Fun. That’s my main reason for being, I guess you could say. To have fun. So, show me a good time, darling. I’m sure we can get to know each other very well.”

She took a step forward and rubbed the top of her head against your chin. You shuddered. It felt...so good. This was such a bizarre situation to find yourself in...and yet...something inside of you felt so right next to this-- fourth-dimensional being?

She put a hand on your chest and looked up into your eyes with warm brown eyes. “So, what do you want to do first?”

info.brief_description: One day on your way home from school, you discover a rock containing a mischievous spirit.
info.description:
It's a seemingly normal day when a gem containing an all-powerful reality-shaper crashes down in your neighborhood. The being inside takes a liking to you and you're off, twisting and bending reality to your will with the help of your new friend! Be very careful with what you say to her, though-- nigh-omnipotent beings are notoriously fickle!

CHARACTERS:

Derek Hallenburg: You. You're a sixteen year old kid with a lot of creative energy. You're also known as a bit of a punk around school. Or a nerd. It depends on who you talk to.

Angela Hallenburg: Your younger sister. Eleven years old. Totally annoying. She loves pranking you, your mom, your dad, and just about everyone actually.

Calliope Hallenburg: Your mom. 43. A good, hard-working person who hardly seems to have time for you or your sister nowadays. She works as a reporter for the local newspaper.

Benjamin Hallenburg: Your older brother. 21. He moved away a couple of years ago to move in with his girlfriend. That was just fine by you. He was nothing but a jerk to you when he lived with you.

Edward Hallenburg: Your dad. 49. A hard-ass. You're not terribly fond of him and he's not terribly fond of you. He thinks you're a lazy excuse for a son compared to your older brother. A career police officer.

Teddy Aldridge: Your best friend. 16. He kicks ass and takes names! Not really. A decent guy who has your back. He could be more popular, if it wasn't for his friendship with you.

Brenda Miller: Your other best friend. 16. A total, hopeless nerd. You two met in kindergarten and you've been inseparable ever since. You do your best to protect her from the realities of high school.

Missy Kirkland: The most popular girl in school and an unrepentant bully. 17. You still have a crush on her, though.

Tommy Lancaster: The most popular guy in school. Also a bully. Not a jock, though. He's class president, but that doesn't mean he's not a dick. Hates your guts.

Jinkies: A fourth-dimensional being living in a three-dimensional world. She's taken the shape of Velma from Scooby-Doo for some reason. You don't know much about her, but she does have the ability to shape and bend reality to her will. For some reason, she's following your lead, but that might change. She seems a little mischievous and a lot fickle. Try to stay on her good side, okay?
